resources.string: Task helps us understand how the usage of your phone is linked to the activities you perform
Activity tells us the big picture and is one of the bricks forming the routine
Ex: If you are planning a trip on your mobile while in class, here,
Activity: Being in the class / Studying
Would you like to answer a couple of\nquestions about your current activity?
Consent Form for Participation in Research
Study Title: Understanding Behavior of Android Users

Principal Investigator:
Julian Ramos
Human-Computer Interaction Institute, School of Computer Science,
Carnegie Mellon University
5000 Forbes Ave
Pittsburgh, PA, 15213.
Phone: 412.708.8874 
Email: ingenia@andrew.cmu.edu
Faculty Advisors: Prof. Anind K. Dey\n

You are being asked to volunteer for a research project studying your behavior when using mobile devices. The study will explore how people on their mobile devices (e.g. smartphones) go through their everyday activities. Based on the finding of the study we will propose and implement designs which will enable faster and easier use of applications on future mobile devices.\n

In order to study your daily mobile device use, we will ask you to install an application that will monitor your device use on your mobile device. Upon installation, the application will ask you to accept this consent form in order to take part in the study. You will be able to use the application only if you give your consent. The application will collect information about other applications that you install, invoke, and use on the device. In addition, the application will unobtrusively collect other contextual information that will help us understand the context in which you interact with your device: current time, cell tower IDs, WiFi access point information, location information, screen status, battery status, network status, and call and SMS events. The locations information will also used for the purpose of activity recognition. The application will store this information on your device and transmit this information to one of our servers over secure connection. The application will also ask you some questions that will pop-up based on some triggers. Your answers to these questions will also be stored on the device and transmitted with the other data.

The study will last 4 weeks. After 2 weeks, there will be a slight change in the application but the data collected will be the same.
You must be 18 years old or older, and own and use an Android mobile device on regular basis.\n

The risks and discomfort associated with participation in this study are no greater than those ordinarily encountered in daily life when using a mobile device (e.g., a cell phone). The only additional discomfort would be that you would have to answer the questions. The only risk is associated with privacy of the data collected. Confidentiality section below describes how this risk is managed.\n
There may be no personal benefit from your participation in the study but the knowledge received may be of value to humanity.\n
You will receive $40 for your participation in the study. You will not receive any additional compensation for your participation in the study.\n

By participating in the study, you understand and agree that Carnegie Mellon may be required to disclose your consent form, data and other personally identifiable information as required by law, regulation, subpoena or court order. Otherwise, your confidentiality will be maintained in the following manner:

Your data and consent form will be kept separate. Your consent form will be stored in a locked location on Carnegie Mellon property and will not be disclosed to third parties. By participating, you understand and agree that the data and information gathered during this study may be used by Carnegie Mellon and published and/or disclosed by Carnegie Mellon to others outside of Carnegie Mellon. However, your name, address, contact information and other direct personal identifiers in your consent form will not be mentioned in any such publication or dissemination of the research data and/or results by Carnegie Mellon.

The researchers will take the following steps to protect participantsâ€™ identities during this study: (1) Each participant will be assigned a number; (2) The researchers will record any data collected during the study by number, not by name; (3) Any original recordings or data files will be stored in a secured and password protected location accessed only by authorized researchers.

Your participation is voluntary. You are free to stop your participation at any point. Refusal to participate or withdrawal of your consent or discontinued participation in the study will not result in any penalty or loss of benefits or rights to which you might otherwise be entitled. The Principal Investigator may at his/her discretion remove you from the study for any of a number of reasons. In such an event, you will not suffer any penalty or loss of benefits or rights which you might otherwise be entitled.\n
Right to Ask Questions And Contact Information

If you have any questions about this study, you should feel free to ask them now. If you have questions later, desire additional information, or wish to withdraw your participation please contact the Principle Investigator by mail, phone or e-mail in accordance with the contact information listed on the first page of this consent.

If you have questions pertaining to your rights as a research participant; or to report objections to this study, you should contact the Research Regulatory Compliance Office at Carnegie Mellon University. Email: irb-review@andrew.cmu.edu . Phone: 412-268-1901 or 412-268-5460.

By accepting below, you agree that the above information has been explained to you and all your current questions have been answered. You understand that you may ask questions about any aspect of this research study during the course of the study and in the future. By clicking accept below, you agree to participate in this research study.\n
